questions.text: Which of the following events is likely to take place during the act of vomiting?

choices.text: Peristaltic movements in the small intestine

questions.solution:
Elevation of the hyoid bone takes place during the act of vomiting.

The sensory signals that initiate vomiting are located in the pharynx, oesophagus, stomach, and upper portions of the small intestines. Excessive distention or irritation of the duodenum provides a strong stimulus for vomiting. Area postrema constitutes the vomiting centre.

Antiperistalsis, or reverse peristalsis, usually starts in the early stages of vomiting. It begins far down in the ileum and travels up to the duodenum and stomach resulting in their distention. This distention becomes the exciting factor that initiates the act of vomiting.

The following events take place at the onset of vomiting (1) the breath is held at mid-inspiration, (2) the hyoid bone and larynx are elevated to pull the upper esophageal sphincter open, (3) closure of the glottis to prevent aspiration of vomitus into the lungs, and (4) lifting of the soft palate to close the posterior nares. 

The diaphragm then contracts strongly downward and all of the abdominal wall muscles contract simultaneously. This squeezes the stomach between the diaphragm and the abdominal muscles, raising the intra-abdominal pressure to a high level. Ultimately, the lower oesophagal sphincter fully relaxes, enabling the stomach's contents to be expelled through the oesophagus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old-lady with CKD presents with bilateral limb muscle weakness and fasciculations. On investigation, her serum potassium level was found to be 6 mEq/L. What is the likely mechanism to have caused her clinical features?

choices.text: Resting membrane potential of nerves is hyperpolarised
Resting membrane potential moved closer to the threshold potential
Resting membrane potential moved away from threshold potential

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly lady with CKD presenting with bilateral limb muscle weakness and fasciculations along with serum potassium levels of 6 mEq/L (normal levels: 3.5-5) is suggestive of hyperkalemia. Resting membrane potential moved closer to the threshold potential is the likely mechanism to have caused her clinical features. 

Resting membrane potential (RMP) is the difference in the electrical potentials between the cytoplasm of the cell and the extracellular space. 

At rest, there are more open K+ channels compared to Na+ channels, thus the membrane permeability of K+ is greater. As a result of this, the intracellular and extracellular K+ concentrations are the major determinants of the RMP. Furthermore, the RMP is close to the equilibrium potential of K+ in general. 

In hyperkalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is increased. Thus the RMP moves closer to the threshold to elicit an action potential leading to a more excitable nerve. The excitable nerve stimulates the muscle repeatedly causing fasciculations, exhaustion of muscle, and weakness.

In hypokalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is reduced. Thus the RMP is reduced and the neuron is hyperpolarized.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with resting tremors, difficulty in initiating movements, poor balance, and frequent falls. What is the site of the lesion of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario of the elderly man presenting with resting tremors, difficulty in initiating movements, poor balance, and frequent falls is suggestive of Parkinson's disease, and the site of the lesion is substantia nigra.

Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans. It shows an accumulation of synucleins. Bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremors, and postural instability are classic features of Parkinson's disease.

Other options:

Option B: Thalamus plays a role in memory, emotions, the sleep-wake cycle, and in the processing of sensory information and relaying it to the cortex. Lesions in the thalamus are seen in a multitude of disorders including vascular diseases, metabolic disorders, inflammatory diseases, and infections.

Option C: A lesion in the subthalamic nucleus causes sudden violent involuntary, and flinging movements confined to one side of the body, commonly affecting the proximal muscles of the limbs, a condition called hemiballismus. The movements are seen contralateral to the side of the lesion.

Option D: A lesion in the globus pallidus can give rise to athetosis. This involves spontaneous and continuous writhing movements of the hand, arm, neck, or face.

The image below shows hemiballismus.

An elderly woman presents to the doctor with a 3-month history of easy fatiguability while performing day-to-day activities. On examination, she has pallor. Her hemoglobin level is 10 g/dL. Her laboratory test reports are given below. Which of the following is true regarding the nutrient deficient in this patient?
  Patient
report		 Normal
values
Serum iron
(μg/dL)		 23 50-150
TIBC 
(μg/dL)		 390 300-360
Transferrin saturation
(%)		 19  25-50
Serum ferritin 
(μg/L)		  13

 

30

(females)

choices.text: It is predominantly absorbed from the duodenum
Its uptake is mediated by divalent metal transporter type 2

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly woman presenting with easy fatiguability with pallor and laboratory features of decreased hemoglobin, serum iron, transferrin saturation, serum ferritin, and increased TIBC (total iron binding capacity), suggest iron-deficiency anemia. Iron is predominantly absorbed from the duodenum.

Iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in its absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the enterocyte, the ferric form is converted to the ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1).

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin. The iron in plasma is transported to the required tissues by the protein transferrin. 

Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of the electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed. Several factors can increase or decrease iron absorption. Ascorbic acid increases iron absorption whereas, phytates (in bran, oats, rye fiber), polyphenols (in tea), calcium, and soy protein decrease its absorption.

Therefore, a patient with anemia must be advised to consume red meat and oranges/lemons and to avoid coffee, tea, and calcium tablets while taking iron tablets.

questions.text: A patient with an established diagnosis of peptic ulcer disease is started on omeprazole. Which type of cell membrane transport is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Primary active transport type of cell membrane transport is inhibited by this drug. Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that blocks the H+-K+ ATPase. The proton pump is an example of primary active transport. 

Primary active transport is an active transport mechanism that obtains energy from the hydrolysis of ATP to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient. The transportation of the molecules mainly depends on the carrier proteins.

Important examples of primary active transport: 

  • Sodium-potassium ATPase
  • Proton pump
  • Calcium ATPase

Proton pumps: These are essential for the primary active transport of hydrogen ions. These pumps are mainly present in gastric glands of the stomach and late distal tubules and cortical collecting ducts of the kidney. 

The main function of proton pumps in the parietal cells of the stomach is to secrete gastric acid. The gastric mucosa has abundant mitochondria and this provides the ATPase that is required for the primary active transport of hydrogen ions. 

At rest, the proton pumps lie within the cells in stacks of membrane compartments called tubulovesicles. During the active phase secretion, these tubulovesicles fuse to form canaliculi. This fusion increases the apical membrane of the cells and positions the proton pumps to begin the acid secretion. 

Proton-pump inhibitors like omeprazole form thiophilic sulfenamide cation that irreversibly binds and inactivates the enzyme H+-K+ ATPase. 

Other options: 

Option A: In simple diffusion, the molecules pass directly through the cell membrane along the concentration gradient. It does not require energy and is not carrier-mediated. Examples include the movement of water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen across the cell membrane. 

Option B: In secondary active transport, the transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances against the concentration gradient. Examples include sodium co-transport of glucose and amino acids with sodium and sodium counter-transport of calcium and hydrogen ions. 

Option C: In facilitated diffusion, the molecules are transported via carrier-mediated proteins along the concentration gradient. This transport does not require energy. Examples include the transport of glucose through GLUT (insulin-mediated transport of glucose via GLUT 4).

questions.text: When a pheochromocytoma suddenly discharges a large amount of epinephrine into the circulation, the patient's heart rate would be expected to:

choices.text: Increase because the increase in blood pressure stimulates the carotid and aortic baroreceptors
Increase because epinephrine has a direct chronotropic effect on the heart
Increase because of increased tonic parasympathetic discharge to the heart
Decrease because the increase in blood pressure stimulates the carotid and aortic chemoreceptors

questions.solution:
When a pheochromocytoma suddenly discharges a large amount of epinephrine into the circulation, the patient's heart rate would be expected to increase because it has direct chronotrophic effect on heart.

Effect of Catecholamines on Heart

Both epinephrine and norepinephrine –

  • Increase the force and rate of contraction of the heart by β1-receptors.
  • Increase myocardial excitability, causing extrasystoles and occasionally cardiac arrhythmias.

The differences in the effects are given in the table below 

Norepinephrine

Epinephrine

vasoconstriction via α1-receptors

Vasodilatation in skeletal muscle and the liver via β2-receptors. 

Norepinephrine -> Increases systolic and diastolic blood pressures -> stimulation of carotid and aortic baroreceptors -> reflex bradycardia -> overrides cardio acceleratory effect of norepi­nephrine->cardiac output falls.

Epi­nephrine causes a widening of the pulse pressure but because baroreceptor stimulation is insufficient to obscure the direct effect of the epinephrine on the heart, cardiac rate, and output increase.

questions.text: Which of the following receptor actions of the drug best describes the rationale for adding epinephrine in cardiopulmonary resuscitation?

choices.text: α1 receptor−mediated increase in renin secretion
β2 receptor−mediated increase in cardiac contractility

questions.solution:
The main effects of epinephrine in cardiac arrest are related to its α1 receptor-mediated peripheral vasoconstriction resulting in the redistribution of blood flow to the brain.

Additionally, β1 mediated increase in cardiac contractility may also exert beneficial effects.

The other options incorrectly match the receptor and its functions.

Option B: The β1 receptor promotes cardiac contractility and enhances renin production.

Option D: The β2 receptor causes vasodilation.

questions.text: A patient with organophosphorus poisoning was given atropine. Which among the following effects of atropine is paired correctly with the receptor blocked to produce it?
questions.solution:
Atropine causes tachycardia due to the blockade of M2 receptors in the heart inhibiting the action of acetylcholine on them.

Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist. Muscarinic antagonists block the effects of acetylcholine by binding to and inhibiting muscarinic receptors on effector cells in the peripheral ganglia and the CNS. Atropine is a competitive antagonist of the muscarinic receptors.

Atropine initially blocks these presynaptic M1 receptors. This increases the amount of ACh released at the SA node and causes bradycardia. Then, the progressive increase in the atropine concentration blocks the postsynaptic M2 receptors on the SA node (decreasing the ACh release) decreasing the parasympathetic tone, thereby causing tachycardia.

Other options:

Option A: Mydriasis is caused due to M3 (mainly) and M2 receptors.

Options C and D: Decreased bronchial secretions and bronchodilatation are due to M2 and M3 receptor blockade.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs act via the mechanism depicted in the illustration shown below?
  1. Dobutamine
  2. Interferon
  3. Imatinib
  4. Atropine
  5. Verapamil
  6. Misoprostol
questions.solution:
The given illustration shows the G-protein-coupled receptor pathway for signalling. The drugs that function via this mechanism are dobutamine, propranolol, atropine, misoprostol, montelukast. 

Functional families of GPCRs include beta-adrenergic receptors, muscarinic cholinergic receptors, eicosanoid receptors, and thrombin receptors.

G proteins act as inhibitory and excitatory because of differences in the alpha subunit.

In general, Gs and Gq subtypes are excitatory whereas Gi is inhibitory.

Resting-state:

  • G protein heterotrimer consisting of alpha, beta and gamma subunits forms a complex with G-protein-coupled receptors at the intracellular domain. The extracellular domain of GPCR has the binding domain for hormones and G protein subunits do not directly bind them. 
  • The alpha subunit is bound to GDP 

Binding of ligand results in an activated state: 

  • Alpha subunit undergoes a conformational change
  • Release of GDP and binding of GTP
  • GTP bound alpha subunit dissociates from beta-gamma subunit
  • Both alpha subunit and beta-gamma subunit bind to and regulate effectors only when they are separated 

The illustration below shows the pathway.

Other options:

  • Interferon acts through cytokine receptors, which belong to the structural family of transmembrane, non-enzymes.
  • Imatinib acts via the receptor tyrosine kinases, which belongs to the structural family of transmembrane enzymes.
  • Verapamil acts via the voltage-gated ion channel.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with hyperemesis gravidarum is prescribed domperidone. How does this drug alleviate nausea?

choices.text: Antagonism of D2 receptors in the area postrema
Antagonism of 5HT3 receptors in the vagal nerve terminals
Enhanced dopamine release in the chemoreceptor trigger zone
Agonism of the 5HT4 receptors in the gut

questions.solution:
In a pregnant female with hyperemesis gravidarum, domperidone alleviates nausea by antagonism of D2 receptors in the area postrema.

Domperidone selectively blocks dopamine D2 receptors in the area postrema and chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), key areas involved in nausea and vomiting reflexes.

Uses:

  • Gastroparesis
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum

Adverse Effects:

  • Cardiac: Increased risk of serious ventricular arrhythmias, especially at higher doses (>30mg/day) and in older adults (>60 years).
  • Neurological: Extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., dystonia, tardive dyskinesia) mainly in individuals with pre-existing conditions.
  • Hormonal: Elevated prolactin levels leading to galactorrhea, gynecomastia, amenorrhea, or impotence.

Other options:

Option B: Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Headache and dizziness are the common adverse effects.

Option C: Domperidone does not enhance dopamine release in the chemoreceptor trigger zone. Its D2 receptor blockade would be expected to decrease dopamine activity in this area. 

Option D: 5HT4 stimulation of excitatory motor neurons enhances acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction and triggers the peristaltic reflex. The 5HT4 agonist action is shown by metoclopramide, cisapride, mosapride, itopride, and renzapride.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding neonatal jaundice is true?
  1. Exclusively breastfed infants have a different pattern of physiological jaundice as compared to artificially fed babies
  2. Breastfeeding jaundice occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding
  3. Breast milk jaundice occurs due to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
  4. Breastfeeding should be stopped to establish the diagnosis of breastmilk jaundice
  5. Breastfeeding should not be stopped for treatment of breastmilk jaundice
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 2, and 5.

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

  • Exclusively breastfed infants have a different pattern of physiological jaundice as compared to artificially fed babies. (Statement 1)
  • Early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. 
  • Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth) 
  • Due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. (Breastfeeding failure jaundice) (Statement 2)
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed

Breast milk jaundice (BMJ)

  • Late-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. (Statement 3)
  • Occurs after the 7th day with maximal concentrations as high as 10–30 mg/dl reached during the 2nd-3rd week.
  • Due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk (etiology not entirely clear).
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels; phototherapy may be of benefit in some cases. (Statement 4)
  • Breastfeeding is not stopped for the treatment of breast milk jaundice. (Statement 5)

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of poor growth, weakness, abnormal gait, and bowing of the legs. The head appears as seen in the image below. Laboratory investigations revealed low serum levels of vitamin D. All of the following findings can be seen in this patient except
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, the clinical features of the patient and low serum vitamin D levels point to a diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency rickets in the patient. The image shows frontal bossing seen in rickets. This condition is associated with an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. 

Nutritional rickets commonly occur due to the deficiency of vitamin D, thereby affecting the metabolism of calcium and phosphate ions in the body. Vitamin D is mainly synthesized by the following mechanism -

This active vitamin D stimulates and increases the absorption of Ca2+  ions from the intestine. It does so by increasing the formation of calbindin which is a calcium-binding protein, that transports calcium into the cells. 

Thus, in vitamin D deficiency, low calcium levels may be seen in the blood. To raise this serum calcium, the secretion of the parathyroid hormone rises and causes - 

  • Reabsorption of calcium in the kidneys and decreases renal calcium excretion
  • Secretion of phosphate ions in exchange, leading to an increase in renal phosphate excretion 
  • Increase in bone turnover 
  • Increases the level of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase which leads to more production of the active form of Vitamin D - 1,25 dihydro cholecalciferol.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: A healthy woman with a normal pregnancy is being evaluated during her antenatal visit. Which of the following is likely to be seen in her thyroid profile?
questions.solution:
Free T3 (triiodothyronine), free T4 (thyroxine), and TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) levels remain normal during pregnancy. Therefore, normal free T3 levels are likely to be seen in the thyroid profile of a healthy woman with normal pregnancy.

Endocrine glands show physiological changes during pregnancy to meet the extra demands of the growing fetus. Maternal total T4 and T3 levels are increased during the early period of gestation due to stimulation of the thyroid gland by hCG (α-subunit of hCG is similar to TSH). TSH levels in the first trimester decline slightly (but remain in the normal range). The level of TSH is normal during the second and third trimesters.

The physiologically important free T4 and free T3 levels are unchanged due to the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG). Hence, pregnant women remain euthyroid.

questions.text:
Identify the correct sequence of maturation of sperms in spermatogenesis.
  1. Spermatozoa
  2. Spermatogonia
  3. Spermatocytes
  4. Spermatid
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 2, 3, 4, 1.

Spermatogenesis begins in adolescence. The complete process takes about 74 days, and about 300 million sperms are produced daily.

questions.text:
The structures involved in the auditory pathway are -
  1. Superior olivary nucleus
  2. Nucleus of the medial lemniscus
  3. Superior colliculus 
  4. Medial geniculate body
  5. Superior temporal gyrus
questions.solution:
The structures involved in the auditory pathway are 1, 4, and 5, i.e, the superior olivary nucleus, medial geniculate body, and superior temporal gyrus.

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is -

  1. Vestibulocochlear nerve
  2. Cochlear nucleus
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex - superior temporal gyrus

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A 72-year old man presented with complaints of reduced vision in the right eye. Kinetic perimetry revealed right homonymous hemianopia. What is the most likely location of the defect in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The most likely defect in this patient presenting with right homonymous hemianopia is in the left optic tract. Homonymous hemianopia involves a loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

Other options:

Option A - A lesion affecting the optic chiasma produces heteronymous hemianopia. It involves loss of vision on the opposite sides of visual fields in both eyes. 

Options C and D - Lesions of the retina and optic nerve affect the visual field of only that eye. The visual field of the opposite eye is normal. 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text:
You inject lidocaine around a sebaceous cyst prior to excising. Which of the following processes contribute to its local anesthetic action?
  1. Inhibition of Na channel
  2. Potentiation of K channel
  3. Inhibition of K channel
  4. Potentiation of Ca channel
  5. Inhibition of Ca channel
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 3 and 5.

The mechanisms of action of local anesthetics like lidocaine include:

  • Inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels
  • Inhibition (not potentiation) of K and Ca channels
  • Inhibition of Transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1)

However, the main action of local anesthetics is mediated by the inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels.

questions.text: As a part of evaluation, a psychiatrist enumerates all the colors of the rainbow to his patient. The next day, when the patient was asked to recollect these colors, he was unable to recollect the 6th color. The doctor mentioned the first few letters of the color, and then the patient answered. The function of which part of the brain is evaluated here?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, priming is being assessed, which depends on the functioning of the neocortex.

Priming is a form of nondeclarative memory that helps in recognizing words or objects to which the person was exposed previously. It is usually assessed by checking for increased reading speed, faster naming of objects, and faster recollection of getting a clue when presented with previously exposed information.

Memory is usually divided into two forms:

  • Explicit or declarative memory is associated with consciousness or awareness.
  • Implicit or non-declarative memory does not involve awareness and its retention. It does not involve the hippocampus in its processing.

Memory can also be classified as:

Short-term memory- lasts for a few seconds to minutes. Working memory is a form of short-term memory. It keeps the information available, usually for a very short time, until the individual plans some action based on it.

Long-term memory can be recollected after years or even for a lifetime. These memories are stored in various parts of the neocortex. The various types of the memories such as visual, auditory, olfactory, etc., are localized to the cortical regions.

Other options:

Option 1: Striatum forms a part of the basal ganglia and is involved in decision-making functions, such as motor control, emotion, habit formation, and reward.

Option 2: Amygdala, a component of the limbic system, is responsible for the control of emotions, behavior, and memory formation. 

Option 3: Cerebellum is responsible for the coordination of movement, maintaining posture and balance, muscle tone, and motor learning.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

Related Pearl: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.
    • The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.
  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

  • Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?
  • Digit span test.

Concentration:

  • Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?
  • Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account
  • Count backward from 20.
  • Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: You observe that the arms of an infant extend spontaneously when the senior resident tries to elicit the following reflex by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. All the following options regarding this reflex are true, except ______.

choices.text: This reflex is  a prerequisite to walking.
This reflex starts to appear by 7–8 months of age.
This reflex disappears by 18 months of postnatal period.

questions.solution:
The reflex being elicited in the given scenario is the parachute reflex, and this reflex remains throughout life.

The parachute reflex can be evoked by holding the infant's trunk and then suddenly lowering it as if it were falling. This will cause the infant's arms to extend in order to break the fall. Thus, it is a prerequisite for walking. The onset of this reflex is at 7-8 months of age; it fully develops by 10-11 months and persists for life. 

The parachute reflex is a primitive reflex. Primitive reflexes appear and disappear at specific times during a child's development. Any persistence or absence of these reflexes is significant for central nervous system dysfunction.

questions.text: In a case-control study, lung compliance of two different groups (1 and 3) was compared against that of the control group (2) and recorded as shown in the graph below. Which of the following cases likely represents groups 1 and 3, respectively?
questions.solution:
Graphs 1 and 3 correspond to decreased and increased compliance, respectively. Among the given options, pulmonary fibrosis is associated with decreased compliance, and pulmonary emphysema is associated with increased compliance.

The extent to which the lungs will expand for each unit increase in transpulmonary pressure is called lung compliance. The total compliance of both lungs together in normal, adult averages about 200 mL of air/cm H2O transpulmonary pressure.

  • The curve is shifted downwards in case of decreased compliance. 
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance.

Here the compliance is 3 > 2> 1.

Compliance is increased in normal ageing lungs and pulmonary emphysema due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched). 

Compliance is decreased in pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary edema, and unventilated lungs due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive airway disease in which there is scarring and stiffening of the lungs. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung
